wjones127 commented on a change in pull request #9828:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9828#discussion_r606722791



##########
File path: docs/make_gandiva_func_index.py
##########
@@ -0,0 +1,128 @@
+# Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one
+# or more contributor license agreements.  See the NOTICE file
+# distributed with this work for additional information
+# regarding copyright ownership.  The ASF licenses this file
+# to you under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the
+# "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance
+# with the License.  You may obtain a copy of the License at
+#
+#   http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0
+#
+# Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing,
+# software distributed under the License is distributed on an
+# "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY
+# KIND, either express or implied.  See the License for the
+# specific language governing permissions and limitations
+# under the License.
+
+'''Generates a RST file containing all Gandiva function signatures
+
+This is meant as a temporary script until we begin writing docs for Gandiva funcs.'''

Review comment:
       Right now this just lists the available function signatures and does so in an automated way. I hope we later have hand-written documentation for the functions. For example, we likely need to explain somewhere what the difference is between `equal`, `eq`, `same`, and `is_not_distinct_from`. (I myself have no idea 😵.)
   
   I plan on starting a thread in the mailing list to discuss the most maintainable way to setup that function documentation.




--

amol- commented on a change in pull request #9828:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9828#discussion_r676470504



##########
File path: docs/Makefile
##########
@@ -66,12 +66,16 @@ help:
 	@echo "  coverage   to run coverage check of the documentation (if enabled)"
 	@echo "  dummy      to check syntax errors of document sources"
 
+
+gandiva_func_docs:
+	python make_gandiva_func_index.py

Review comment:
       It would probably be better to make a sphinx extension out of this.
   For example in Turbogears, to generate the `cogbin` (this page https://turbogears.org/cogbin.html ) we made a `cogbin.rst` ( https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TurboGears/tgwebsite/master/src/cogbin.rst ) which contains the `.. cogbin` directive. That directive is custom and will be replaced with the list of python packages that you see in the final page. Support for the custom cogbin directive is shipped within the sphinx source itself as `cogbin.py` ( https://github.com/TurboGears/tgwebsite/blob/master/src/cogbin.py#L204-L217 ) and it's just enalbed in the doc `conf.py` ( https://github.com/TurboGears/tgwebsite/blob/master/src/conf.py#L28 )
   
   Likewise for the YouTube directive to embedd YT videos ( https://github.com/TurboGears/tgwebsite/blob/master/src/youtube.py )
   
   Obviously the custom directives can emit other `rst` (which I think it's what we want here) or directly `html` etc...




--

Review comment:
       It would probably be better to make a sphinx extension out of this.
   For example in Turbogears, to generate the `cogbin` (this page https://turbogears.org/cogbin.html ) we made a `cogbin.rst` ( https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TurboGears/tgwebsite/master/src/cogbin.rst ) which contains the `.. cogbin` directive. 
   That directive is custom and will be replaced with the list of python packages that you see in the final page. 
   Support for the custom cogbin directive is shipped within the turbogears documentation source itself as `cogbin.py` ( https://github.com/TurboGears/tgwebsite/blob/master/src/cogbin.py#L204-L217 ) and it's just enalbed in the doc `conf.py` ( https://github.com/TurboGears/tgwebsite/blob/master/src/conf.py#L28 )
   
   Likewise for the YouTube directive to embedd YT videos ( https://github.com/TurboGears/tgwebsite/blob/master/src/youtube.py )
   
   Obviously the custom directives can emit other `rst` (which I think it's what we want here) or directly `html` etc...

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9828#issuecomment-913826940


   @amol- I started refactoring into a custom directive, but I found myself thinking the function list really wouldn't be that useful without clarifications of most of the functions. There's a lot of small details that are only described in unit tests or code comments. So I instead created hand-written documentation similar to the Available Functions section in the Compute documentation.

wjones127 commented on PR #9828:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9828#issuecomment-1253802344

   I was having a hard time getting reviews on my Gandiva PR, plus I had changed jobs and wasn't planning on using Gandiva anymore. There aren't very many active Gandiva maintainers (most activity I've seen if a few people adding functions) and almost none of them are familiar with PyArrow, so it was difficult to get reviews and merged. After a while, I was reticent to document a submodule that doesn't have people committed to maintain it. So I closed it.
   
   If the situation changes and there's more maintainers on Gandiva and the PyArrow bindings specifically, we should definitely reopen this.

KirillLykov commented on PR #9828:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9828#issuecomment-1253886558

   @wjones127
   
   > 
   
   
   
   > I was having a hard time getting reviews on my Gandiva PR, plus I had changed jobs and wasn't planning on using Gandiva anymore. There aren't very many active Gandiva maintainers (most activity I've seen if a few people adding functions) and almost none of them are familiar with PyArrow, so it was difficult to get reviews and merged. After a while, I was reticent to document a submodule that doesn't have people committed to maintain it. So I closed it.
   > 
   > If the situation changes and there's more maintainers on Gandiva and the PyArrow bindings specifically, we should definitely reopen this.
   
   From what you've said (aligned with my impression), I think it might make sense to spin off Gandiva from the Apache Arrow.

wjones127 commented on PR #9828:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9828#issuecomment-1253929055

   > From what you've said (aligned with my impression), I think it might make sense to spin off Gandiva from the Apache Arrow.
   
   I'm not sure I understand how spinning off would help. Spinning off would require more maintenance work than keeping and working within the repo.
   
   If there are people / companies actively using Gandiva in PyArrow, hopefully some of them can come forward and take on active maintenance.

js8544 commented on PR #9828:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9828#issuecomment-1253947907

   > > From what you've said (aligned with my impression), I think it might make sense to spin off Gandiva from the Apache Arrow.
   > 
   > I'm not sure I understand how spinning off would help. Spinning off would require more maintenance work than keeping and working within the repo.
   > 
   > If there are people / companies actively using Gandiva in PyArrow, hopefully some of them can come forward and take on active maintenance.
   
   Hi Will, would you mind merging the C++ docs to master first? They seem complete already except for the newly added functions. I am currently maintaining Gandiva and plan to improve its document based on your work.
   
   As for Gandiva in PyArrow, my company has long term plans to use it but not in the near future. Meanwhile I'll try my best to maintain it if needed.

wjones127 commented on PR #9828:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9828#issuecomment-1253952037

   Sure @js8544, I'll reopen a PR later today with the C++ user guide.

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
I am looking at using Gandiva's Python bindings in an experimental project, and noticed there aren't any Sphinx docs. Assuming it's not too early, I would be willing to add documentation in Sphinx.

Two starting points for documentation:
 * A how-to for creating filters and projections using the builders. The first part of this blog post gives the right idea: [https://blog.christianperone.com/2020/01/gandiva-using-llvm-and-arrow-to-jit-and-evaluate-pandas-expressions/]
 * API reference. If possible, it would be cool to have a table listing all of the available functions in the registry.
fields.summary: [Python][Gandiva] Add Gandiva documentation to Python docs

comments.body: Oh whoops. Missed that Gandiva was dropped from latest wheels (in a PR that shrunk the size of wheels: [https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/7334]). So it may be worth waiting on this until we create a separate wheel, as per https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-8518.

[~willjones127] Adding more documentation about pyarrow.gandiva would be very welcome!

I don't think it necessarily needs to wait for ARROW-8518, eg gandiva is still included in the conda packages

I couldn't find a separate Jira about C++/Gandiva documentation, so will write here.
I would like to add example of using gandiva on C++ and would be interested in early feedback.
In particular, I had in mind to write a simple hand-written parser for sql-like language with variables and arithmetical operations (+,-,*) and probably some logical expressions (filtering). I though to limit number of variables to three and use predefined values to simplify the code.
